user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_BSP_EndTest:
```c
void UT_BSP_EndTest(const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *TestCounters)
{
    char Message[128];

    /*
     * Only output a "summary" if there is more than one test Segment.
     * Otherwise it is a duplicate of the report already given.
     */
    if (TestCounters->TestSegmentCount > 1)
    {
        UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport("SUMMARY", TestCounters);
    }

    snprintf(Message, sizeof(Message), "COMPLETE: %u tests Segment(s) executed\n\n",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->TestSegmentCount);

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(Message, strlen(Message));
    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    if ((TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE] > 0) ||
        (TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF] > 0) || (TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF] > 0))
    {
        OS_BSP_SetExitCode(OS_ERROR);
    }
    else
    {
        OS_BSP_SetExitCode(OS_SUCCESS);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
snprintf(Message, sizeof(Message), "COMPLETE: %u tests Segment(s) executed\n\n",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->TestSegmentCount);
explanation: The selected fragments are all places where the parameter TestCounters is dereferenced or passed to another function and therefore are the only locations relevant to Rule 17.8 (modification of a function parameter or the pointer itself). No assignment to the parameter variable TestCounters appears anywhere in the function (there is no statement like "TestCounters = ..."), so there is no direct modification of the pointer itself in other lines. Other code fragments (declaration and use of the local array Message, calls to UT_BSP_Lock/Unlock, OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl, and OS_BSP_SetExitCode) do not reference or modify the TestCounters parameter and therefore do not need investigation under this rule.
